item.title: Triple j Unearthed winner has high hopes for Hottest 100 - ABC News
item.description:
Triple j Unearthed winner has high hopes for Hottest 100  ABC News

A nine-to-five was never going to cut it for Melbourne musician Tash Sultana. "My mum pushed me to get a normal job when I finished school and I just wasn't into that at all," she said. "So I hit the street and started busking and making my own way." Soon after, she was stopping crowds on Bourke Street, many surprised to see only one person making the music. Sultana taught herself how to play about 10 instruments including guitar, percussion and piano, as well as saxophone, Arabic oud, and American pan pipes. She plays solo, looping and layering her sounds. "I just go into one, I don't feel...

item.title: Triple J Hottest 100: does Australia's youth broadcaster have an identity crisis? - The Guardian
item.description:
Triple J Hottest 100: does Australia's youth broadcaster have an identity crisis?  The Guardian

On Thursday, as people settled down for their Australia Day barbeques – which have been soundtracked by Triple J’s Hottest 100 listener poll since 1989 – tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets in Australia’s capital cities to condemn the ongoing celebration of the day and the plight of Indigenous Australians more broadly. There’s nothing ambiguous in the call made by activists to cease celebrating the date: it does, after all, mark the day in 1788 that Arthur Phillip’s fleet landed in Sydney Cove, thus setting in motion centuries of violent colonisation and oppression of Indige...

item.title: Triple J Hottest 100 crib notes: up-and-coming artists set to sweep the countdown - The Guardian
item.description:
Triple J Hottest 100 crib notes: up-and-coming artists set to sweep the countdown  The Guardian

With a record-breaking 2,255,110 votes cast in this year’s poll, the Triple J Hottest 100 returns on 26 January – although whether or not that’s the right date for it depends on which side of the debate you’re on. After his sweep of the Arias in November, Sydney’s Harley Streten – AKA Flume – has been tipped for the top spot, for his track Never Be Like You. But it’s neck and neck with Amy Shark – AKA “where did she come from?” – close behind. Or close in front, depending which side of the debate you’re on. Shark isn’t the only name you may be hearing for the first time tomorrow. There are ...

item.title: Is this our last Aus Day Hottest 100? - The Advertiser
item.description:
Is this our last Aus Day Hottest 100?  The Advertiser

IS THIS the final countdown?

item.title: To keep Triple J's Hottest 100 on Australia Day is structural racism. The date must change - The Guardian
item.description:
To keep Triple J's Hottest 100 on Australia Day is structural racism. The date must change  The Guardian

I used to love Australia Day. Every year my friends and I, boom box on our shoulders, would go from house to house dressed in board shorts, singlets and pluggers variously emblazoned with the Australian flag. Any excuse to drink far too much with my friends really – and this excuse was delivered with a public holiday, some lamb, and a national countdown, the Hottest 100. I loved it. I would get shivers down my spine when that deep booming voiceover revved up and said “number 100”. Blissfully ignorant to the fact that Indigenous Australians were being excluded simply because of the date. 26 ...

item.title: Give us a day of celebration for all - The Advertiser
item.description:
Give us a day of celebration for all  The Advertiser

This makes it inappropriate as our national day because it’s dividing rather than uniting us. Unlike some who brand it little more than political correctness, I support changing the date. The latest organisation to explore the issue is ABC youth radio station Triple J, which is considering moving the date of its Australia Day Hottest 100 countdown. The countdown has been part of Australia Day for years. Interestingly, January 26 only became a national holiday in 1994 — which makes it younger than the Hottest 100. It’s time for us to acknowledge that the day is now seen as too loaded to be w...

item.title: Triple J still considering moving Hottest 100 Countdown away from Australia Day - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Triple J still considering moving Hottest 100 Countdown away from Australia Day  mUmBRELLA*

National youth broadcaster Triple J has revealed it is still reviewing whether its annual countdown of the station’s most popular songs of the year should occur on the January 26 public holiday. In September, Triple J announced the date for the broadcast of the Hottest 100 was under review. Yesterday the station issued an update on the review’s progress, noting “consultation will continue throughout the first half of 2017”. “Triple J has been and will continue to consult a variety of groups on the differing perspectives of 26 January. We’re consulting with the ABC Bonner Committee, who are ...

item.title: ABC ponders Hottest 100 shift - The Australian
item.description:
ABC ponders Hottest 100 shift  The Australian

The survey is designed to gather listeners’ opinions on the date of the countdown in response to a wider community backlash against January 26 being the date on which our national day is celebrated. The date has widely been recognised as a day of mourning for Aboriginal people, who see Australia Day as commemorating British arrival rather than the nation’s ancient culture. The issue has been debated since 1938, when the first Day of Mourning was convened in Sydney, but came to a head again last year. In Perth, the City of Fremantle moved some of its Australia Day events to January 28, citin...

item.title: The ‘other’ radio countdown today - The Advertiser
item.description:
The ‘other’ radio countdown today  The Advertiser

IT’S the other countdown on January 26 — Smooth FM’s Top 500 is the alternative to the alternative Hottest 100.

item.title: Bieber and Beyonce? Hottest 100 shocks hipsters - The Advertiser
item.description:
Bieber and Beyonce? Hottest 100 shocks hipsters  The Advertiser

SYDNEY electronic musician Flume has beaten Gold Coast singer Amy Shark to win this year’s Triple J Hottest 100.

item.title: Triple j's Hottest 100 kicks off for another Australia Day - ABC News
item.description:
Triple j's Hottest 100 kicks off for another Australia Day  ABC News

The ABC's triple j Hottest 100 has kicked off for 2017, counting down Australians' favourite songs of the past year. The poll began at noon AEDT with Birds of Tokyo's Brace, followed by Drake ft Rihanna's Too Good and Glass Animals' Season 2 Episode 3. This year's listener-generated countdown is the biggest ever, with a record 2,255,110 votes cast in the 2016 ballot. Those listening at home can tune in on radio. Here's a frequency finder to make sure you're dialled in. triple j Hottest 100 quiz Spend some time challenging your mates to our triple j Hottest 100 quiz. You can also enjoy the t...

item.title: Australian Music prize: AB Original become first Indigenous act to win $30,000 award - The Guardian
item.description:
Australian Music prize: AB Original become first Indigenous act to win $30,000 award  The Guardian

AB Original – the hip-hop pairing of the rapper and actor Briggs and the producer Trials – has become the first Indigenous act to win the $30,000 Australian Music prize, beating shortlisted artists including Nick Cave and the Avalanches. “It sucks to be them,” Briggs laughed, of their competitors. “Normally it sucks to be us!” Briggs said the win, which they accepted at an event in Melbourne on Thursday night, was a “reflection of all the artists that came before us, who allowed us to be able to walk up tonight and win this”, listing Archie Roach, Kutcha Edwards and Ruby Hunter among others...

item.title: Best trolling of triple j Hottest 100 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Best trolling of triple j Hottest 100  The Advertiser

It’s the same every Australia Day. The countdown plays in the background as you’re getting sh*tfaced on cheap beers in your backyard, occasionally throwing out a sophisticated “Faaaaaaaack I love this song!” or “Yerrrrrrr jokin’ mate!” when that one Peking Duk song that sounds like all those other Peking Duk songs plays too early. If you were keeping up with the countdown on social media, you may have noticed one gallant Facebook user perfectly trolling the top 100 list on Facebook. The official triple j Facebook page, which has over one million followers, issues a post for every song that ...

item.title: Relive the Hottest 100 top 10 countdown - ABC News
item.description:
Relive the Hottest 100 top 10 countdown  ABC News

Flume has won triple j's Hottest 100 countdown with his song Never Be Like You featuring Kai. Australian artists took out eight of the top 10 spots. Relive the 2016 top 10 with our playlist: #10 The Weeknd - Starboy (featuring Daft Punk) External Link: The Weeknd - Starboy ft. Daft Punk #9 Peking Duk - Stranger (featuring Elliphant) External Link: Peking Duk - Stranger ft. Elliphant #8 Flume - Say it (featuring Tove Lo) External Link: Flume - Say it (ft. Tove Lo) #7 Illy - Papercuts (featuring Vera Blue) External Link: Illy - Papercuts (featuring Vera Blue) #6 DMA's - Believe (triple j Like...

item.title: Everything you need to know about triple j's Hottest 100 - ABC News
item.description:
Everything you need to know about triple j's Hottest 100  ABC News

It's as Australian as sausage sizzles, the Boxing Day Test and Acca/Dacca. Triple j's Hottest 100 is back, and this year will be bigger than ever. So, how do you tune in to a marathon playlist of 2016's best tunes? And what's so special about the poll anyway? How do I listen in, and when? The countdown begins at 12:00pm (AEDT), but you don't have to be in Australia to tune in. What time to tune in: - WA: 9:00am - NT: 10:30am - SA: 11:30am - QLD: 11:00am - NSW/ACT/VIC/TAS: 12:00pm Hottest 100 parties around the world can all listen in no matter where they are — just follow triple j's handy t...

item.title: Hottest 100 runner-up goes to No.1 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hottest 100 runner-up goes to No.1  The Advertiser

AMY Shark lost out to Flume on the Hottest 100 but the Gold Coast singer is set to become the breakout artist from the Triple J countdown.

item.title: JJJ seeks new Hottest 100 date - The Australian
item.description:
JJJ seeks new Hottest 100 date  The Australian

Would you prefer to see the famous countdown moved to a less contentious date, or are you just there for the “tunes and the party” and “don’t really care what day it’s on?” These are some of the questions the ABC is asking as it conducts a review aimed at finding a “more respectful and inclusive” date for one of summer’s key events: the Australia Day Hottest 100 countdown. In a survey launched yesterday, Triple J listeners were asked to describe how they feel about the Hottest 100 being held on January 26, with suggested answers ranging from: “It’s a chance to celebrate some of my favourite...

item.title: Triple J opens the voting lines for the Hottest 100 - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Triple J opens the voting lines for the Hottest 100  mUmBRELLA*

Triple J’s Hottest 100 has opened it’s voting for the Australia Day competition. The announcement: Triple J’s Hottest 100 voting is open + Dr Karl does a showy for science The time has come to agonise over your fave songs of the year, coz voting is now open for triple j’s Hottest 100! Every year hundreds of thousands of listeners from all over the world tell us which songs they think make the cut, culminating in a list of the 100 biggest songs of the year. The chosen songs which make up the list mark a distinct moment in time, such as The Rubens ‘Hoops’ (2015), Chet Faker’s ‘Talk Is Cheap’ ...

item.title: Searching for the funniest school kids in Australia - ABC News
item.description:
Searching for the funniest school kids in Australia  ABC News

Sirak Keeghan is a 16-year-old student at University High School in Victoria. He came to Australia from Ethiopia when he was four years old. What distinguishes him from others who may share his aversion to doing homework, or who cop sideways looks for their brown face in a predominantly white country, is something uniquely Australian, and distinctively potent as a weapon in any uncomfortable situation — it's Sirak's ability to make people laugh. And whatever else he may like to say about his life, it's getting the laugh that's paramount. "I never go too deep," he mused on his comedy. "If yo...

item.title: From Hottest 100 to Dami Im: Australian music’s 10 biggest talking points of 2016 - The Guardian
item.description:
From Hottest 100 to Dami Im: Australian music’s 10 biggest talking points of 2016  The Guardian

1. Dami Im ‘robbed’ at Eurovision In 2015 Australia entered the Eurovision song contest as a wild card and Guy Sebastian turned in a surprisingly decent Bruno Mars impersonation. Australia loves the song contest more than some of Europe does (I’ve never seen a Brit respond with anything other than contempt over the unjustness of political voting), so it was nice of Eurovision to let us enter again. Dami Im performed a perfect Eurovision song this year, showy and dramatic, and came a respectable second. Our response was atypical, however. We complained about being robbed; we pored over the n...

item.title: Hottest 100 breaks voting and Aussie artist records - ABC News
item.description:
Hottest 100 breaks voting and Aussie artist records  ABC News

Australian music producer Flume has beaten Gold Coast singer Amy Shark to claim the top spot in the triple j Hottest 100 2016 countdown for his song Never Be Like You featuring Kai. Relive the Hottest 100 top 10 Flume has won triple j's Hottest 100 countdown with his song Never Be Like You featuring Kai. Relive the top 10 with our playlist. It is the first time the 24-year-old has reached the number one spot. Never Be Like You dominated the charts in 2016 after its release in January and was number one on the ARIA singles chart. Flume chartered three other times throughout the countdown wit...

item.title: ABC revolving door continues - The Australian
item.description:
ABC revolving door continues  The Australian

One of the ABC’s most senior executives, Michael Mason, is departing the national broadcaster after 34 years. Mr Mason, director of regional and local and previously director of radio, who helped to develop Richard Fidler’s Conversations and supervised Triple J’s decision to move its Hottest 100 countdown away from Australia Day, told staff in an email today that his resignation was not linked to the ABC board’s sacking of managing director Michelle Guthrie and the subsequent resignation of chairman Justin Milne. “This decision was made in early August, well before the departure of former M...

item.title: ABC chairman tried to stop triple j moving date of Hottest 100, sources say - ABC News
item.description:
ABC chairman tried to stop triple j moving date of Hottest 100, sources say  ABC News

ABC chairman Justin Milne tried to stop triple j moving the Hottest 100 music countdown because he was afraid of what Malcolm Turnbull would say, sources have told Hack. Around mid-2017, after extensive consultation and a massive listener survey, triple j privately briefed the ABC board on its decision to move the date of the Hottest 100 music countdown away from Australia Day to a nearby weekend. It presented independent research showing a majority of listeners (60 per cent) were in favour of moving the Hottest 100 to a different date. However, ABC board chairman Justin Milne did not suppo...

item.title: ABC becomes the story after high-profile departures - ABC News
item.description:
ABC becomes the story after high-profile departures  ABC News

Michelle Guthrie's sacking took everyone by surprise, but it was only the first twist in what has become a tumultuous week for the ABC. The drama kicked off on Monday morning when ABC chairman Justin Milne emailed staff, informing them the managing director had been sacked. Columnists and commentators speculated about the board's move but, generally, critiques focused on her leadership style, a perceived lack of communication with staff and sketchy understanding of the media. Mr Milne, however, declined to be specific, telling ABC presenter Joe O'Brien: "I'm not going to go into that." Ms G...

item.title: Amy Shark: 'I had given up. I never thought I’d get to do this' - The Guardian
item.description:
Amy Shark: 'I had given up. I never thought I’d get to do this'  The Guardian

Amy Shark remembers very clearly the day her song Adore was added to rotation on Triple J. “Everyone contacted me.” Her phone rung off the hook as excited label managers, booking agents and prospective management companies realised she was unsigned. Within a week, Shark was being flown from Australia to New York at the behest of Republic Records. “I was meeting so many people and it was so, so ridiculous,” Shark recalls. “I’d been trying to get these people’s attention for so long.” By the time January 2017 rolled around – less than six months after the track made its radio debut – Shark ha...

item.title: Kendrick Lamar interrupts show to stop white fan from rapping the N-word - ABC News
item.description:
Kendrick Lamar interrupts show to stop white fan from rapping the N-word  ABC News

When US rapper Kendrick Lamar tours Australia later this year, think twice before expertly dropping all the lyrics to HUMBLE. Video has emerged of the Pulitzer Prize-winning artist interrupting a show in Alabama to ask a white fan to refrain from singing the N-word in his lyrics. The fan had been invited onstage at the Hangout Festival at Gulf Shores, where Lamar was the headlining act, to rap his 2012 hit M.A.A.D city, which contains the racial slur a total of 15 times. Deconstructing HUMBLE. The context, themes and legacy of Kendrick Lamar's Hottest 100 winning song. Accounts posted onlin...

item.title: Kendrick Lamar is doing an Australian arena tour - ABC News
item.description:
Kendrick Lamar is doing an Australian arena tour  ABC News

Hottest 100-winning US rapper Kendrick Lamar has announced a tour of Australia this winter in addition to his appearance at Splendour in the Grass. The Pulitzer Prize-winning artist will hit arenas in Perth, Melbourne, Adelaide and Sydney in July. The 30-year-old Californian will tour off the back of his latest album, DAMN., which has sold millions of copies and spawned chart-topping singles. It won the Grammy for Best Rap Album — one of five Lamar won that night — and topped many publications' end-of-year lists. The track HUMBLE. won the Hottest 100. Deconstructing HUMBLE. The context, the...

item.title: Hottest 100: Californian rapper Kendrick Lamar wins Triple J poll - The Guardian
item.description:
Hottest 100: Californian rapper Kendrick Lamar wins Triple J poll  The Guardian

Kendrick Lamar has become the first person of colour to win the Triple J Hottest 100, a milestone for the annual countdown after it was moved from its broadcast on Australia Day for the first time since 2004. Lamar’s incendiary hit Humble was widely tipped to come in at No 1 on the list of Triple J listeners’ favourite songs of the year. The California rapper has released three critically acclaimed and uncompromisingly political albums, and his highly anticipated 2016 record Damn, intended to be “a hybrid” of his first two albums, became his most commercially successful. Related: Kendrick L...

item.title: Baker Boy reveals an unlikely fusion of Indigenous roots and Fred Astaire - ABC News
item.description:
Baker Boy reveals an unlikely fusion of Indigenous roots and Fred Astaire  ABC News

Forget about Cloud 9. The sky's the limit for Yolngu rapper Baker Boy, who has had a year beyond his wildest dreams — with two songs cracking into triple j's Hottest 100. Danzel Baker, aka Baker Boy, 21, burst onto the music scene in May with his first single, Cloud 9, which hit 76 in the Hottest 100. His follow-up track, Marryuna, reached 17. Born and raised in the remote Top End communities of Milingimbi and Maningrida, the now Melbourne-based Baker Boy takes his name from the dance duo formed by both his father and uncle Jeremiah in the 1980s, The Baker Boys. His uncle Jeremiah said Danz...

item.title: The one Hottest 100 classic you'll never hear on the radio - ABC News
item.description:
The one Hottest 100 classic you'll never hear on the radio  ABC News

In the history of the Hottest 100, 1997 was a memorable year. Australian band The Whitlams took out the top spot with No Aphrodisiac, a slinky piano ballad. The deeply divisive Tubthumping by Chumbawamba ("I get knocked down, but I get up again …") came in at number three, while Radiohead had two tracks from their career-defining OK Computer in the top 10. This weekend, the day after the world's biggest music poll, Double J is replaying that Hottest 100 from 20 years ago. But there's one song on that list that won't be broadcast. Two decades on, radio stations still can't play it for you — ...

item.title: What time does the Hottest 100 start? - ABC News
item.description:
What time does the Hottest 100 start?  ABC News

Are you ready for the most important music countdown in the land? The triple j Hottest 100 starts at midday AEDT. You can listen on the radio, online or via the ABC's Listen app. The countdown will run until evening, with number one generally announced about 8:00pm. It's going to be a big year in the history of the world's biggest music poll. Not only has there been a date change, but this year broke records for the number of votes cast (more than 2.3 million). That's up 5 per cent on last year, when Flume's Never Be Like You (ft Kai) took out the number one spot. What can we expect? Hottes...

item.title: Hottest 100 crib notes: who's set to sweep the countdown? - The Guardian
item.description:
Hottest 100 crib notes: who's set to sweep the countdown?  The Guardian

This year, for the first time since 2004, Triple J’s Hottest 100 won’t be held on 26 January. After a long campaign by Indigenous activists and supporters, and a nationwide survey of its listeners, the broadcaster announced in November that the date of its annual countdown would be moving permanently to the fourth Saturday of January. Conservative media was outraged. Triple M, somewhat embarrassingly, launched its own Australia Day countdown. But, by and large, the world continued to turn. Hotly tipped to take out first place in this year’s poll is the US rapper Kendrick Lamar with HUMBLE.,...

item.title: Analysis: Crunching the numbers on Hottest 100 classics - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Crunching the numbers on Hottest 100 classics  ABC News

This year's triple j Hottest 100 promises to be a memorable one, and not just because of the youth network's controversial recent decision to move the countdown of the world's largest annual online music poll away from Australia Day. A record 2,386,133 votes have been cast and it's a chance for the songs of 2017 to make their pitch for posterity. What makes a classic song? In our research, to be published in the journal Economic Record, we have analysed every Hottest 100 song dating back to 1993. (We have also looked at 2013's one-off Hottest 100 of the Past 20 Years and the five Hottest 10...

item.title: Live: The Hottest 100 is in full swing — follow along - ABC News
item.description:
Live: The Hottest 100 is in full swing — follow along  ABC News

It's that time of year again where Australia's national youth broadcaster, triple j, counts down your favourite songs of the past year. Who will take out the coveted number one spot in the world's biggest music poll? Follow along as we catalogue each song as it's played. External Link: Follow live: triple j Hottest 100

item.title: Aussie song analysis shows our wordiest artists - ABC News
item.description:
Aussie song analysis shows our wordiest artists  ABC News

Pop songs are dumb and getting dumber, and hip-hop is the dumbest genre of them all. Or so screamed headlines reporting a 2015 analysis which calculated "readability" scores for lyrics from US chart-topping hits of the previous decade. Turns out the songs were mostly pitched at the reading level of US grade 2 or 3 — that's kids aged seven and eight — and had dropped half a grade from 2005. So we thought we'd have a bit of fun and use the same technique to work out how Aussie songwriters shape up. To qualify for our "highly scientific" lyric analysis treatment, a songwriter's work had to hav...

item.title: Kesha embraces #metoo moment with performance of Praying - ABC News
item.description:
Kesha embraces #metoo moment with performance of Praying  ABC News

American musician Kesha has taken the #metoo cause to the Grammys with a powerful performance of Praying, a song many believe was written about the singer's former alleged abuser. Kesha's music career was stalled for years owing to a protracted legal dispute with her former producer, Dr Luke, who she has accused of physical, sexual and emotional abuse. The song she performed, Praying — written with Ryan Lewis and Australian musician Ben Abraham — has been her comeback hit. Many have noted it appears to be addressed to an abuser: 'Cause you brought the flames and you put me through hell I ha...

item.title: BuzzFeed launches ‘What They Don’t Teach You’ documentary series ahead of Australia Day - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
BuzzFeed launches ‘What They Don’t Teach You’ documentary series ahead of Australia Day  mUmBRELLA*

BuzzFeed has launched a three-part documentary series, What They Don’t Teach You, as part of the site’s week-long campaign looking into the history and contemporary realities faced by indigenous communities during the week of Australia Day. In the documentary series, indigenous affairs reporter Amy McQuire documents the past, present and future of Aboriginal Australia and looks at the pain and grief relating to Australia Day’s origins and how Australians can heal the wounds of the past. McQuire travels across Australia documenting first nation stories McQuire was appointed BuzzFeed’s indige...

item.title: 'Intolerant censorship': Bernardi lashes musicians' criticism of alternative Hottest 100 list - ABC News
item.description:
'Intolerant censorship': Bernardi lashes musicians' criticism of alternative Hottest 100 list  ABC News

Cory Bernardi has told Australian artists asking to be removed from his party's "alternative to the Hottest 100" playlist that they should be thankful for the royalties, after one band included in the list told him to "f*** off". The senator's Australian Conservatives party announced the #AC100 yesterday, saying the move was prompted by triple j's decision to move its annual Hottest 100 countdown away from Australia Day this year. The party released a Spotify playlist of tracks from Australian artists and invited people to vote for their favourites. But some artists, including Savage Garden...

item.title: Move aside, Cory Bernardi - check out my song list - The Advertiser
item.description:
Move aside, Cory Bernardi - check out my song list  The Advertiser

It’s a bit like discovering Donald Trump and I both like McDonalds and KFC – colonic irrigation suddenly sounds attractive. Anyway, Bernardi (or a clever spin doctor, at least) has revealed an alternative Hottest 100 playlist in protest at Triple J’s “politically correct” decision to change the date of its hugely popular countdown of the nation’s top 100 Australian songs from January 26. Of course, one man’s political correctness is another’s empathy for Aboriginal Australians who feel it’s an insult to celebrate Australia Day on the very day whites arrived and declared the country empty. F...

item.title: Men At Work singer slams Bernardi's alternative music countdown - ABC News
item.description:
Men At Work singer slams Bernardi's alternative music countdown  ABC News

Men At Work frontman Colin Hay has slammed South Australian senator Cory Bernardi's attempt to start his own Hottest 100 playlist. Senator Bernardi, who leads the Australian Conservatives Party, is asking people to vote in what he has termed an "alternate Hottest 100", following triple j's decision to change the date of its annual music poll from Australia Day. But Hay, whose song Down Under is first on Senator Bernardi's Spotify list, said the meaning of his song had been hijacked by the politician's poll. "It would appear that the true meaning behind Down Under is lost on Mr Bernardi," he...

item.title: Savaged: Cory Bernardi's alternative Hottest 100 stunt riles musicians - The Guardian
item.description:
Savaged: Cory Bernardi's alternative Hottest 100 stunt riles musicians  The Guardian

“Get over yourself, Darren Hayes,” said a conservative federal senator to an Australian pop music icon, because that’s apparently where we’re at now. Wednesday’s tussle between Cory Bernardi and one half of Savage Garden took place on the frontline of the culture wars – Twitter – after Bernardi announced he wanted to DJ Australia Day. Hilltop Hoods took up sweary arms to stand with Hayes, and by Thursday afternoon Powderfinger,Jimmy Barnesand the music platform Spotify had also weighed in. Still annoyed that the radio station Triple J responded to a majority of its polled listeners and move...

item.title: Baker Boy rising: from Arnhem Land to sharing a stage with Dizzee Rascal - The Guardian
item.description:
Baker Boy rising: from Arnhem Land to sharing a stage with Dizzee Rascal  The Guardian

On stage, Baker Boy is the kind of rapper who can get a crowd airborne within seconds. He’s all ego, gold chains and boundless energy, flitting between his native Yolngu Matha and English, imploring the audience to “step back, feel the power of my blackness”. He commands the mic and didgeridoo as if they’re extensions of his tall, agile frame, and inverts himself mid-flow with audacious breakdancing moves. Related: ‘A mic drop on the nation’: how AB Original’s January 26 galvanised a movement He is the first Indigenous artist to have mainstream success rapping in the Yolngu Matha language, ...

item.title: Triple M's plan to run 'Ozzest 100' is an embarrassing plea for attention - The Guardian
item.description:
Triple M's plan to run 'Ozzest 100' is an embarrassing plea for attention  The Guardian

I must admit something straight off the bat. I forgot Triple M existed. It has been a while since I’ve been around white men aged 45 and over. I know that white men aged 45 and over need a safe space, and I’m glad it still exists in Triple M. They announced yesterday that they were going to give what “you’ve asked for.” Related: Indigenous artists criticise Triple M's decision to run Australia Day top 100 It’s not clear who “you” is or when “you” have asked for this, or if Triple M is the station people were asking it from, but they insist on delivering. I know a lot of people have criticis...

item.title: Indigenous artists criticise Triple M's decision to run Australia Day top 100 - The Guardian
item.description:
Indigenous artists criticise Triple M's decision to run Australia Day top 100  The Guardian

Indigenous writers, artists and organisations have voiced their disappointment at Triple M’s decision to host its own version of the Hottest 100 on Australia Day. Adam Briggs, who makes up one half of the Indigenous hip-hop duo, AB Original, called on fans to hijack Triple M’s countdown by voting for his song January 26, which argues for changing the date of Australia Day. “Fuck up the party before it even starts!” he wrote on Twitter. Briggs said Triple M’s decision to run the program, titled “Ozzest 100”, pandered to nationalists and racists. Hey! Vote for January 26 by @ABOriginalBAM & @...

item.title: Triple M stands by Australia Day ‘Ozzest 100’ despite growing backlash - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Triple M stands by Australia Day ‘Ozzest 100’ despite growing backlash  mUmBRELLA*

Southern Cross Austereo’s Triple M has refused to back down on plans to air an “Ozzest 100” countdown on Australia Day in a move it has linked to ABC station Triple J’s decision to move the date of the Hottest 100 to a less divisive date. Triple M sent out an email to its subscribers yesterday, announcing the launch of its “perfect Australia Day” soundtrack. It criticised the “hipsters” of Triple J for deciding there would be no soundtrack on Australia Day. Three weeks ago, Triple J announced it had changed the date of its annual Hottest 100 countdown to recognise criticism from the Indige...

item.title: Ian the Climate Denialist Potato makes a statement on Triple J's Hottest 100 - The Guardian
item.description:
Ian the Climate Denialist Potato makes a statement on Triple J's Hottest 100  The Guardian

Ian the Climate Denialist Potato makes a statement on Triple J's Hottest 100

item.title: Triple J to move Hottest 100 away from Australia Day after ‘Invasion Day’ concerns - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Triple J to move Hottest 100 away from Australia Day after ‘Invasion Day’ concerns  mUmBRELLA*

ABC youth network Triple J will be moving its Hottest 100 countdown from Australia Day to January 27, the national broadcaster has announced. In recent years, the network has come under pressure to move the Hottest 100 after criticism from Indigenous communities and organisations that holding the show on ‘Invasion Day’ is insensitive and inflammatory. A review was launched following last year’s Hottest 100 involving Indigenous groups and the ABC’s Bonner Committee – the organisation’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues advisory panel – which was followed by a listener survey. The ...

item.title: Hottest 100: AB Original and Dan Sultan praise date change at Arias - The Guardian
item.description:
Hottest 100: AB Original and Dan Sultan praise date change at Arias  The Guardian

Australian musicians, including Dan Sultan and the Indigenous rap duo AB Original, have praised Triple J’s decision to move the date of the Hottest 100, calling it “a beautiful gesture” that marks “the difference between whether you’re an arsehole or a nice person”. Speaking on the red carpet at Tuesday night’s Aria awards, Briggs, of AB Original, said the decision reflected “how the majority of people feel” and was a welcome “step towards equity and inclusivity”. “It’s a dumb day, it’s stupid. Australia Day is trash. 14 years old. We’ve got 80,000 years of history here and you want to cele...

item.title: ABC will be asked to reconsider triple j's Hottest 100 decision - ABC News
item.description:
ABC will be asked to reconsider triple j's Hottest 100 decision  ABC News

The ABC's board will be asked to reconsider triple j's decision to move the date of its highly successful Hottest 100 countdown away from Australia Day, according to the Communications Minister. The scheduling change was announced yesterday and has caused significant brouhaha among politicians, with some criticising the ABC for seeking to "delegitimise" Australia Day. Triple j management argue the Hottest 100 was not created as an Australia Day celebration, and it had consulted with its audience, the music industry and Indigenous Australians about whether changing the date was necessary. "T...

item.title: The connection between the Hottest 100 furore and the NBN farce spelled out in seven words - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
The connection between the Hottest 100 furore and the NBN farce spelled out in seven words  mUmBRELLA*

Dr Mumbo felt rather sorry for sleepy communications minister Mitch Fifield when he plodded onto ABC News Breakfast this morning to attempt to generate some heartland-pleasing condemnation of Triple J’s decision to shift it’s Hottest 100 rundown to a less divisive day than Australia Day. Although Fifield’s heart clearly wasn’t really in it, he gave it a shot. Communications Minister @SenatorFifield has accused @triplej of making a “political statement” by moving the #Hottest100 countdown pic.twitter.com/5nzzhyGpsF — News Breakfast (@BreakfastNews) November 27, 2017 After all, it was better ...

item.title: Hottest 100 won't be held on Australia Day, triple j says - ABC News
item.description:
Hottest 100 won't be held on Australia Day, triple j says  ABC News

The Hottest 100 will not be held on Australia Day next year, triple j says, with the station acknowledging the "increasing debate" about January 26 and its meaning for Indigenous Australians. Next year's countdown will instead be held on Saturday January 27, with the songs that just missed out — places 101 to 200 — being played on the Sunday. In 2016, the station said it would be reviewing the tradition of holding the countdown on Australia Day, adding it was "heavily involved in the growing dialogue around Indigenous recognition and perspectives on 26 January". Since then, the station has ...

item.title: It shouldn't have taken a survey to move the Hottest 100 from Invasion Day - The Guardian
item.description:
It shouldn't have taken a survey to move the Hottest 100 from Invasion Day  The Guardian

I admit it: I have not listened to the Triple J Hottest 100 for a number of years, despite my sworn love for independent Australian music and media. And no, it’s not because nowadays I am more the Double J demographic. Triple J has been my go-to radio station while I travel all over the country for a long time now. Rather, I haven’t been listening because due to the fact that the countdown has been held on 26 January, I have been otherwise engaged. This year, for example, I was busy helping 50,000 other people shut down the streets of Melbourne at the Invasion Day rally. Last year I attende...

item.title: Here's what you think about triple j moving the Hottest 100 date - ABC News
item.description:
Here's what you think about triple j moving the Hottest 100 date  ABC News

The Hottest 100 will be held on Saturday, January 27 next year. Triple j says the countdown "should be an event that everyone can enjoy together — for both the musicians whose songs make it in and for everyone listening in Australia and around the world." But how do you feel about the decision? We asked. You responded. Many of you think it's a great move "Good idea. We have so many talented Aboriginal artists featured in the count. To do it on Jan 26 is disrespectful to their heritage. Good call." — Ben Clapton "Triple J has taken advantage of its platform and influence of young Australians...

item.title: Arias 2017: Gang of Youths poised for wins at Australia's biggest music awards - The Guardian
item.description:
Arias 2017: Gang of Youths poised for wins at Australia's biggest music awards  The Guardian

In a recent interview, Gang of Youths’ frontman, David Le’aupepe made reference to the “arc” of his, life. “The whole point of [Gang of Youths’ latest album] Go Farther in Lightness was to make … the arc of my life, more or less, about the process of repairing,” he told the Music. It makes sense that Le’aupepe, lead singer of the Sydney five-piece, thinks of his life like a story, with character arcs, emotional journeys and Big Themes. The band’s albums are constructed like Homeric poems, full of lessons and trials and tests. They are grand indie epics made in the image of Arcade Fire’s Fun...

item.title: Arias 2017: Gang of Youths, Paul Kelly and AB Original lead celebration of music and change - The Guardian
item.description:
Arias 2017: Gang of Youths, Paul Kelly and AB Original lead celebration of music and change  The Guardian

Gang of Youths and Paul Kelly were the big winners at the 31st Aria awards, on a night that saw Indigenous rap duo AB Original declare “change doesn’t come from everyone being comfortable” after Triple J’s decision to move the date of the Hottest 100. On their way to winning best independent release and best urban release, rappers Briggs and Trials delivered the performance of the night with Kelly and Dan Sultan. Their updated, explicitly political, cover of Dumb Things saw Briggs rap the now-prescient line: “The date’s changin’.” “We made this album for our community, in our community, fro...

item.title: Govt criticises Hottest 100 move - The Australian
item.description:
Govt criticises Hottest 100 move  The Australian

Senior govt ministers have criticised Triple J's decision to move its Hottest 100 from Australia Day.

item.title: Did Triple J get it wrong on Hottest 100? - The Advertiser
item.description:
Did Triple J get it wrong on Hottest 100?  The Advertiser

Communications Minister Mitch Fifield has written to the Chair of the ABC to request the broadcaster reconsider the change. “Triple J and the ABC should not be inserting themselves into political debates with decisions like this,” he told the Senate in Question Time today. And it seems many readers concur with his point of view. A poll of readers of News Corp websites in Australia today showed more than two thirds of respondents believed Triple J had made the wrong decision. By 5.40pm AEDT, more than 800 readers had responded to the poll, with 67.37 per cent saying Triple J had made the wro...

item.title: ‘A mic drop on the nation’: how AB Original’s January 26 galvanised a movement - The Guardian
item.description:
‘A mic drop on the nation’: how AB Original’s January 26 galvanised a movement  The Guardian

Archie Roach is normally the gentlest of our Indigenous protest singers. He writes songs of great moral force and clarity but his voice, even after the ravages of age and illness, is quiet and hymnal, giving his work a bittersweet quality that allows him to connect easily with a broad audience. The song that introduced him to most Australians, Took the Children Away, remains the one for which he is most famous. Its opening lines are: “This story’s right, this story’s true I would not tell lies to you.” Related: It shouldn't have taken a survey to move the Hottest 100 from Invasion Day | Cel...

item.title: A.B. Original win Album of the Year J Award for Reclaim Australia - ABC News
item.description:
A.B. Original win Album of the Year J Award for Reclaim Australia  ABC News

Indigenous hip-hop duo A.B. Original, whose song January 26 was one of the most controversial of last year's Hottest 100, have scored the Album of the Year J Award for their debut record Reclaim Australia. The 12-track record, which won the coveted Australian Music Prize in March (one of a few gongs the pair have picked up this year), pulls no punches on issues of Indigenous disadvantage, and features collaborations with Dan Sultan, Archie Roach and others. January 26, which was released as a single last year and came in at number 16 in the 2016 Hottest 100, is unflinchingly political, with...
